title: How to Find Your Router's IP Address: Mobile, PC, Mac, Chromebook, & Linux

steps.title: Install WiFi Analyzer (open-source) from the Google Play Store.
steps.content: Install WiFi Analyzer (open-source) from the Google Play Store. Because most Android models can't display the IP address of the router you're connected to, you'll need to install a free app. Fortunately, this app has great reviews and is highly recommended online. Open the Play Store app on your Android phone or tablet. Search for wifi analyzer . Tap WiFi Analyzer (open-source) from VREM Software Development, which has a green icon containing white curved lines. [1] X Research source Tap Install to get the app.

steps.title: Open Wifi Analyzer and tap the menu icon ☰.
steps.content: Open Wifi Analyzer and tap the menu icon ☰ . It's the three horizontal lines at the top-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Access Points.
steps.content: Tap Access Points . You will now see a list of Wi-Fi routers, with the one you're currently connected to at the top of the list.

steps.title: Find your router's IP address below its name.
steps.content: Find your router's IP address below its name. The IP address appears at the bottom of your router's tile next to the connection speed (e.g., 72Mbps).

steps.title: Open the Settings app .
steps.content: Open the Settings app . You'll find this gear icon on your Home screen, in your app list, or by searching.

steps.title: Tap Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Tap Wi-Fi . It's near the top of the Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap the lowercase "i" in a circle next to your Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Tap the lowercase "i" in a circle next to your Wi-Fi network. This displays information about your current connection.

steps.title: Find your router's IP address next to "Router."
steps.content: Find your router's IP address next to "Router." You may have to scroll down a little to see it. To copy your router's IP address, just tap and hold the address, then tap Copy . This makes it easy to paste into your web browser so you can log in and make configuration changes .

steps.title: Open the Command Prompt.
steps.content: Open the Command Prompt. You can use a quick Command Prompt command to find your router's IP address in any version of Windows, including Windows 11, Windows 10, and Windows 8. To open Command Prompt: Press the Windows key on your keyboard. Type cmd . Click Command Prompt in the search results.

steps.title: Type ipconfig and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type ipconfig and press ↵ Enter . This displays information about all network connections on your PC.

steps.title: Find the router's IP address next to "Default Gateway."
steps.content: Find the router's IP address next to "Default Gateway." If you're connected to the router via Wi-Fi, you'll see your router's IP address under "Wireless LAN adapter Wi-Fi" (or similar). If you're using an ethernet cable, it will be under "Ethernet adapter." You can now use this IP address to access your router's configuration panel.

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings .
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . It's the gear icon in the left-side column of the Start Menu. You can also open Settings by pressing Windows key + I on your keyboard.

steps.title: Click Network & Internet .
steps.content: Click Network & Internet . It's the globe icon.

steps.title: Click View your network properties.
steps.content: Click View your network properties . It's at the bottom of the right panel below "Network troubleshooter."

steps.title: Find the router's IP address next to "Default gateway."
steps.content: Find the router's IP address next to "Default gateway." This number is the IP address of your router. You can navigate to this address in your web browser to configure your router .

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings .
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . It's the gear icon in the left-side column of the Start Menu. You can also open Settings by pressing Windows key + I on your keyboard.

steps.title: Click Network and Internet.
steps.content: Click Network and Internet . You'll see this option in the left panel.

steps.title: Click Advanced Network Settings.
steps.content: Click Advanced Network Settings . This option is at the bottom of the right panel.

steps.title: Click your current connection.
steps.content: Click your current connection. For example, if you're connected to your router via Wi-Fi, click the Wi-Fi option at the top.

steps.title: Click View additional properties.
steps.content: Click View additional properties . It's just below "Rename this adapter."

steps.title: Find your router's IP address next to "IPv4 address."
steps.content: Find your router's IP address next to "IPv4 address." You can now use this IP address to access your router's configuration website in any web browser.

steps.title: Click the Apple menu and select System Settings.
steps.content: Click the Apple menu and select System Settings . You'll see the Apple menu at the top-left corner of the screen. If you're using macOS Monterey or earlier, select System Preferences from the Apple menu instead.

steps.title: Click Network.
steps.content: Click Network . On macOS Ventura and later, you'll see this option in the left panel. On Monterey and earlier, the Network option is the outline of a globe.

steps.title: Select your network connection.
steps.content: Select your network connection. For example, if you're connected to the internet via Wi-Fi, select your Wi-Fi connection.

steps.title: Click Details (macOS Ventura) or Advanced (earlier versions).
steps.content: Click Details (macOS Ventura) or Advanced (earlier versions). This displays information about your current connection, including your Mac's IP address .

steps.title: Find your router's IP address.
steps.content: Find your router's IP address. You'll see this IP address next to "Router." If you're using macOS Monterey or earlier, you may have to click the TCP/IP tab at the top of the panel to see your router's IP Address.

steps.title: Click the time at the bottom-right corner of your taskbar.
steps.content: Click the time at the bottom-right corner of your taskbar. This opens your quick settings and notifications. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Chromebook's Settings .
steps.content: Open your Chromebook's Settings . To open Settings, click the time at the bottom-right corner, then click the gear icon.

steps.title: Click the Network menu.
steps.content: Click the Network menu. It's at the top of the left panel.

steps.title: Click Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Click Wi-Fi . You'll see this at the top of the right panel. This displays a list of Wi-Fi networks you've connected to on your Chromebook. The network you're connected to now is labeled "Connected."

steps.title: Click the network you're connected to.
steps.content: Click the network you're connected to. Now, you'll see information about your current connection, including your Chromebook's IP address .

steps.title: Click the Network menu to display your router's IP address.
steps.content: Click the Network menu to display your router's IP address. You'll see your router's IP address under "Gateway," along with other information about your connection.

steps.title: Open a Terminal window.
steps.content: Open a Terminal window. Whether you're using Ubuntu, Linux Mint, CentOS, or any other version of Linux, you can easily find your router's IP address with a simple terminal command. On most versions of Linux, including Ubuntu, you can open a Terminal by pressing Ctrl + Alt + T .

steps.title: Type ip r and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type ip r and press ↵ Enter . This displays the IP address of the router you're connected to. You can now use this IP address to make changes to your router, such as changing your Wi-Fi password .
